comments:
Hi,
I know birt currently does not support oracle stored procedures returning ref cursors, so I did a work around writing a table function.
I created my own object type record :

create type emp as object
(emp_no integer, name varchar(50), title varchar(20));

create type empCol as table of emp;

then I created the following function:

CREATE OR REPLACE function fn_getEmp (
     in_empID in number) return empCol pipelined is

     out_emp  req_ex;
     CURSOR c1 (IN_EMP_ID NUMBER) IS
         select emp(emp_id, name,title)
 		FROM employee
 		where emp_id != IN_EMP_ID;
 BEGIN
 OPEN c1(in_empID);
    LOOP
       FETCH c1 INTO out_emp;

       EXIT WHEN c1%NOTFOUND;
       pipe row (out_emp);
    END LOOP;
 	
 close c1;
return;
 end;

in the dataset editor under "query"
I type the following:
select * from table (fn_getEmp(12345))
and it returns a proper result set.
but I want to be able to pass a parameter to the function.

I create a parameter of type integer and change the query too:
Select * from table (fn_getEmp(?))

this gives me the following error from the logs:

Can you pass parameters to a function when you call it???
When you first create a new data set instance to specify your query text, try use the "SQL Select Query" data set type.  Does it have an error?

I just tried creating a new dataset using the "SQL Select Query" option instead of the "stored procedure" option and I got a different error from the one I posted below.  The query will run if I don't use a "?" in the function call.

here is the new error I get:

back to the first scenario (procedure query),I was wondering if you define the parameter after changing the query to "select * from table (fn_getEmp(?))"

by the way, codes to support oracle ref cursor is ready to check-in. you should be able to use cursor in a couple of days,regards

I tried both. 
1.) I created the param then changed the query.
2.) I changed the query then created the param.

And I got the same error below.

Try cursor directly.
You can find more info. on cursor support @bug 117166
thx

it's been a little while since your last post, I was wondering how did the cursor go?
